isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSING SCUFFED INJECTORS - Test Procedure - Using the EST and Master Diagnostics

svcproc.title: Test Procedure - Using the EST and Master Diagnostics

note.para: All of the following screen views are based off of MD32 Version 2.3 default settings unless otherwise stated. You may have variations of views if you are using a different version of MD. If you have customized settings you may have a different view.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, put the transmission in neutral, set the parking brake, and block the drive wheels before starting the engine.

step1.para: Start the engine and bring it up to its normal operating temperature above 160°F (71°C).
Start Master Diagnostics. Select the single box ECM application (MD32 DLC) . Selecting the wrong application will give you erroneous readings.

Connect the EST with the International® truck interface cable to the 6 pin ATA connector located near the left side kick panel. For 9 pin ATA connectors, use the pigtail connector (6 pin to 9 pin) adapter tool ZTSE4467.
Select the Session drop-down menu bar and select Open to begin a session .
Select the file KOER_CCT_I6.SSN (Key-On Engine Running Cylinder Contribution Test) from the Open Session File dialog window. The file name should now appear in the File Name box . Select Open.

svcproc.para: When selecting a factory default session from International® Engine, Master Diagnostics automatically selects the correct COM port. Refer to the Master Diagnostics Software User's Manual for additional information.

step1.para: Verify that the engine coolant temperature (ECT) is greater than 160°F (71°C).

It is essential to run the Key-On Engine-Running Standard Test in order to gain access to cylinder contribution testing. Select the Diagnostics drop-down menu bar, then select the Key-On Engine-Running Standard Test .

svcproc.para: If a diagnostic message appears, take note of the message, select OK and try again. If the message reappears, refer to the Diagnostic Tests section in the MD Software Users Manual.

note.para: The status bar will display the message DIAGNOSTICS RUNNING at the bottom of the screen.

step1.para: When the standard test is complete, select the Diagnostics drop-down menu and select the Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test .
If a diagnostic message appears, take note of the message, select OK and try again. If the message reappears, refer to the Diagnostic Tests section in the MD Software Users Manual.

note.para: The status bar will display the message DIAGNOSTICS RUNNING at the bottom of the screen.

step1.para: While the test is running, the following parameters are observed in the graphical view:

figure.caption: Typical Graphical View - Good Cylinder Contribution

step1.para: The following graphic is an example of how a low fuel delivery injector looks during the test.

figure.caption: Interpreting Graphical Data - Poor Cylinder Contribution

svcproc.para: When the over-fuel condition is compared to the under-fuel condition a significant difference is observed. This indicates that a particular cylinder is a strong contributor, or that the injector and power cylinder are functioning properly providing optimum output. CYL No.1, 2, and 3 show evidence of well defined graphic traces, while CYL No. 4, 5, and 6 are viewed with suspicion. A weak contributing cylinder could be the result of a poorly functioning injector or a mechanical problem.

note.para: Figure represents a graphical replay (SnapShot recording).

specpara.para: The graphical replay provided for interpretation was not severe enough to generate a Diagnostic Trouble Code.

item.para: To maintain constant engine speed the ECM makes greater changes to the fuel rate than seen in weaker cylinders (cylinders 4-6).
There is a greater impact on Engine Load (EL).
To maintain constant engine speed the ECM makes smaller changes to the fuel rate than seen in stronger cylinders (cylinders 1-3).
There is a minimal impact on Engine Load (EL).

svcproc.para: The previously described procedure allows the technician to troubleshoot and repair the engine by replacing only the scuffed or defective injector(s). In the previous example the suspect injector(s) No.6, No.5, No.4, (weak contributors) should be replaced.
If this fails to improve performance or significantly improve the graphical display, further mechanical diagnostic testing is necessary.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, do not start the engine without priming the fuel system. Failure to do so will overload the injector tips. Priming the fuel system will be necessary. It has been found that "dry starts" after engine/fuel system maintenance contributes to injector tip failures. After engine service, when the fuel injection system is dry, cranking the engine to start without first priming the fuel system can result in an overload condition in injector tips. This overload occurs because there isn't any fuel present to cushion the needle valve as it lifts and seats. To avoid this condition, follow the procedure below after performing any maintenance that may allow air to enter the fuel system.

item.para: Use the hand primer to fill the majority of the fuel system. Pump until hand primer is hard to depress.
Crank the engine three times for 15 seconds each. Reapply the hand primer after each crank cycle.
Once the hand primer is hard to depress (usually three crank and hand prime cycles), reconnect the CMP and start the engine.

svcproc.para: In cases where rust or corrosion is present in the injectors, some additional precautions are required.

item.para: Clean the entire fuel system of any water or other foreign contamination, including fuel tanks, fuel filter housings, strainers and fuel supply manifold.
After cleaning the fuel system, install and run existing injectors to purge the fuel system of any remaining contamination. Installation of new injector(s) can then be made.
It is recommended to replace all injectors that show signs of rust or corrosion.

note.para: This may not be a warrantable failure.
